items.title: LeBlanc says he believes U.S. will keep CUSMA trade deal with Canada, Mexico
items.summary_auto: The minister in charge of Canada-U.S. trade says he has no reason to believe the Trump administration is preparing to tear up the free trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, even though the U.S. president and some of his associates have suggested they may consider withdrawing from the pact.

items.title: Baby dies of exposure after storm Byron floods Gaza tents, medics say
items.summary_auto: Torrential rain swept across the Gaza Strip on Thursday, flooding hundreds of tents sheltering families displaced by two years of war and leading to the death of a baby girl due to exposure, local health officials said.

items.title: Would Netflix buying Warner Bros. kill movies in theatres?
items.summary_auto: Some in the movie theatre industry are expressing grave concerns over Netflix's bid to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, worried it poses a threat to the future of theatregoing itself. Meanwhile, industry analysts suggest theatre companies and studios need to do more to give customers faced with rising prices compelling reasons to see movies in cinemas.

items.title: The steaks are high: When beef could finally become cheaper to buy
Sherrone Moore fired as Michigan football coach for inappropriate relationship, detained by police
items.summary_auto: Sherrone Moore was jailed on Wednesday, according to court records, just hours after he was fired as University of Michigan football coach for what the university said was an "inappropriate relationship with a staff member."

items.title: U.S. drubs Canada 10-4 in Rivalry Series hockey game in Edmonton
items.summary_auto: Kelly Pannek and Abbey Murphy each scored twice for the United States in a 10-4 win over Canada in a Rivalry Series game on Wednesday.

items.title: Indigenous fashion models, vendors still waiting for payment after working Sask. fashion show
items.summary_auto: Indigenous models and vendors say they're out hundreds of dollars after participating in a Regina fashion show this fall. The event's organizer says the money is on the way.

items.title: Evacuation orders issued for hundreds in Abbotsford, B.C., amid flood warnings
How this team is transforming health care for African Nova Scotian women
items.summary_auto: The Nova Scotia Sisterhood aims to provide culturally sensitive health-care services to Black women and gender-diverse individuals. The team is working to break down some of the systemic barriers that exist for African Nova Scotians trying to navigate the health-care system.

items.title: Metal found in hamburgers during school-ordered lunch in Burlington, Ont.
items.summary_auto: Two parents are speaking out after students at their children's school in Burlington, Ont., say they found metal in hamburgers the school ordered from a local chain restaurant.

items.title: Months after fatal crash, legacies of 4 Walkerton, Ont., students and their teacher live on
items.summary_auto: In the seven months since a crash that killed a teacher and four teenagers from a Walkerton, Ont., high school, several funds and foundations have been set up to keep memories of the five alive. "The legacy is still there," says Dan Rourke, dad of one of the students who died.

items.title: New rifles on the way for Canada's soldiers as defence spending ramps up
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Army will start to replace its entire stock of assault rifles, starting next year. Internal documents obtained by CBC News show a contract under the Canadian Modular Assault Rifle program is imminent. The deal is expected to boost production at a Canadian arms maker as part of the federal government’s drive to boost the defence industrial base.

items.title: Should everybody be taking Ozempic?
items.summary_auto: We examine the rise and risks of blockbuster drugs like Ozempic, after the WHO conditionally recommended GLP-1s for the long-term treatment of obesity.

items.title: Bundle up and look up! The annual Geminid meteor shower is upon us
items.summary_auto: Baby, it’s cold outside — but it’s worth putting on that heavy winter coat, scarf and boots and heading out for one of the best meteor showers of the year: the Geminids.

items.title: Quebec's health reform didn't just anger doctors. It left hundreds of millions in funding in limbo
items.summary_auto: Hundreds of millions of dollars meant to be invested in Quebec’s beleaguered health-care network remains in limbo more than a month after the Legault government abolished the institute overseeing the funds without warning.

items.title: As Fort William First Nation grieves 5 sudden deaths, its chief calls for more support
items.summary_auto: Chief Michele Solomon says Fort William First Nation is often hit with multiple losses at once, but it never gets any easier. The Ojibway community, which neighbours Thunder Bay, Ont., is grieving the loss of five of its members in recent days. Here are some of the challenges the First Nation in northwestern Ontario is facing.

items.title: Beef prices are soaring. Here's why Canada is facing record-low cattle numbers
items.summary_auto: There is a slight bit of positive news for those who love to grill a steak in the summer or enjoy a roast dinner during the chilly winter months: beef prices are expected to climb further in 2026, but not by as much as in recent years.

items.title: Nunavik ends year with record number of TB cases — and one of the highest rates in the world
items.summary_auto: As of Dec. 10, the region has recorded 112 active cases – the highest reported level in recent history. Provincial and federal officials say ongoing discussions about eliminating tuberculosis across Inuit Nunangat are going well.

items.title: Venezuelan opposition leader Machado greets supporters in Norway after Nobel ceremony
items.summary_auto: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado appeared in public for the first time in 11 months early Thursday morning, when she waved to supporters at a hotel in Norway's capital hours after her daughter accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on her behalf.

items.title: Report alleges national museum CEO mistreated staff, called leadership team 'sluts'
items.summary_auto: Public Sector Integrity Commissioner Harriet Solloway found that Marie Chapman, who holds the most senior job at the Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21 in Halifax, engaged in a pattern of behaviour over a decade that caused emotional harm to employees.

items.title: Homeowner shaken after vandals destroy Christmas inflatables display in Scarborough
items.summary_auto: A Scarborough homeowner is shaken after masked vandals using hammers destroyed a display of large Christmas inflatables on his front lawn over the weekend.

items.title: Holiday precautions to spread cheer, not germs
items.summary_auto: Health officials are reminding Canadians to maintain healthy habits during the holiday season, as influenza leads to more school  absences  and  hospitalizations.

items.title: Alberta boy, 12, pleads guilty to attempted murder of 7-year-old brother
items.summary_auto: A 12-year-old Lethbridge, Alta., boy who “had been researching murder on YouTube” before he stabbed his seven-year-old brother nine times, pleaded guilty to attempted murder Wednesday afternoon.

items.title: Gaza aid deliveries falling short of ceasefire terms: AP analysis
items.summary_auto: Aid deliveries into Gaza are falling far short of the amount called for under the U.S.-brokered ceasefire, according to an Associated Press analysis of the Israeli military's figures as humanitarian groups say the shortfall is severely impacting the strip's two million people.

items.title: Climate change supercharged cyclone damage in parts of Asia, study finds
items.summary_auto: Deadly cyclones with torrential rains are supercharged by warming temperatures, says a new report by the World Weather Attribution group. At least 1,600 people were killed after Cyclones Senyar and Ditwah tore through Malaysia, Thailand and Sri Lanka in late November.

items.title: 'Profound failure of care' led to death of Winnipeg infant who had meth in bloodstream, prosecutor argues
items.summary_auto: A prosecutor says a constellation of events in a Winnipeg home that included unsafe sleeping conditions, rampant drug use and the parents' tumultuous relationship shows a "profound failure of care" in the weeks leading up to the death of a three-month-old in 2022.

items.title: Flooding in parts of B.C.’s Fraser Valley leads to major highway closures, state of emergency
Man accused of attempted murder was discharged from involuntary mental health order, family says
items.summary_auto: The family of a man charged with two counts of attempted murder says they were shocked to learn he'd been released from a community treatment order months ago, and say he was denied vital care before the near-fatal attacks.

items.title: U.S. ambassador downplays fears of Trump administration meddling in Canadian politics
Israel approves hundreds of housing units in 3 settlements in the occupied West Bank
items.summary_auto: Israel has given the go-ahead for the construction of 764 more houses in three Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, a decision likely to further stoke tensions as a watchdog group accused the Israeli government of moving toward "de facto annexation" of the Palestinian territory.
